aÄ±chÄ± @Machy 2022-02-05 #u0qfp0BlO $en +3
â–¯ alieves that â–¯ is the case.
  Machy (2022-02-05): an alief is an idea that, while not considered to be true, nonetheless garners a strong emotional reaction. Like jumping at shadows after watching a horror movie: you believe there's nothing to be scared of, but you're scared anyway. The notion that there's a monster in those shadows is an example of an alief.

  lassc (2022-12-04): +1 for interesting concept and nice word form

aÄ±mu @Hoemai 2022-08-06 #zJJysQXen $en +2
â–¯ is not* the case.
  Hoemai (2022-08-06): This predicate expresses that its argument is false and that this disagrees with a proposition from the immediately preceding discourse (there should be one most salient proposition). Like the opposite of German "doch" and French "si", but as a verb. If no argument is provided, it defaults to the negation of the most salient proposition.
  Hoemai (2022-08-06): A: **Jáº£q chá» hÃ³ jÃ­** B: **AÄ±mu chÃ´ hÃ³ sÃºq**. A: "He really likes me!" B: "No, he doesn't."
  Hoemai (2022-08-06): A: **Gá»‰ hoÄ± fáº£fuaq** B: **AÄ±mu**. A: "That movie is good." B: "No, (it isn't)."
  robintown (2022-10-25): See also **jeha**
  Ilmen (2025-10-31): officialized: yes

aÄ±muru @uakci 2022-11-19 #lZ77iFT1j $en Â±
connective: indeed not X, and Y
  uakci (2022-11-19): similar to **buru** except that it "adds in" a **bu** if one isn't already present in the left connectand
  uakci (2022-11-19): so, both **bá»§ ná»§Ä± aÄ±muru sáº£o** and **ná»§Ä± aÄ±muru sáº£o** are meant to be correct and two different ways of phrasing the same thing (the former requiring less forethought), whereas **bá»§ ná»§Ä± buru sáº£o** would mean the wrong thing (due to double negation)
  uakci (2022-11-19): < **aÄ±mu** + **ru**, in analogy with **buru** < **bu** + **ru**

boq @Isi 2024-09-08 #oPKFOa9-4 $en Â±
predicate: â€˜preventâ€™; â–¯ prevents â–¯ from happening.
  Isi (2024-09-08): The first slot is a thing and the second is an event.
  Isi (2024-09-08): The idea behind these slots being this way: (1) I feel that there's not a big difference between a proposition or event preventing something from happening vs. a thing preventing it from happening. (2) It's possible to prevent a single event from happening but not preventing a different event from making the proposition true; e.g. you could prevent someone's death (by curing their disease), but then they die anyways (for unrelated reasons).
  Isi (2024-09-08): Though I'm not sure if the semantics make sense when you refer to an event that doesn't actually happen.

  fagri (2020-06-19): Fork of #C89LAbatY
  fagri (2020-06-19): This scopes, by the way
  fagri (2020-06-19): Â«Shá»‰kÄqpÅa hÃ³ cÃ²u lÃº máº£Ä± hÃ³a hÃ³ na cÃ²u È·Ã­Â» = "They winked at me at the one who loves them" [they intended me to witness the wink and they intended the third part to witness the wink and my witnessing of it]

deoqzaosu @seaqtaq 2023-03-08 #rt2AkRPuN $en Â±
â–¯ is one's communicative identifier/signature; â–¯ is one's "voice" (not necessarily vocal)
  seaqtaq (2023-03-08): This is an abstraction of english's "voice" across every possible communicative medium, be it sound waves, the electromagnetic spectrum, tactile, olfactory, etc. Intended to be less anthropocentric, as the existence of this word means that it is not necessary to use the metaphor of "voice" to attempt to refer to communicative signatures in general. In addition to being less anthropocentric, it can be used for humans that can't speak as well. The word could be used to refer to the visual pecularities and idiosyncracies of the way one signs a particular sign language as well

  Ilmen (2025-10-12): Why not a different word than the official âŸªduaÄ±âŸ«? I interpret the original as having a focus on the person who is *reponsible* for the duty/obligation, and this new meaning doesn't allow expressing responsability.
  Ilmen (2025-10-12): Admittedly, the wording of the original definition is ambiguous and can also be interpreted as allowing âŸªthe door âŸ¦duaÄ±âŸ§/must be openedâŸ« which is not about responsability. But I suspect this isn't what the original meaning is about, at least if we take into account the verb's frame.
  Ilmen (2025-10-12): I guess if this new definition were to be adopted, âŸªduaÄ±gÄ±laâŸ« could work as a replacement for the previous meaning, but it's a bit longishâ€¦
  Dembim (2025-12-17): just fyi "A is obligated to bring about X" and "it is obligatory that A bring about X" are often considered interchangeable, at least in most cases. "Meinong-Chisholm reduction" I recall there being problems involving plural agents, but I'm not that familiar.
  Dembim (2026-02-04): Having looked into it a bit, I think the problems with impersonal obligation are rather serious. On the other hand, paraphrasing impersonal obligation in terms of an agent-indexed obligation operator alongside some gnomic/generic device seems likely (though I want to do more reading). So, I think <@official duaÄ±> is the better definition, at least if we reconsider the class as ho rather than ta.

  Dembim (2026-02-12): Note that this differs from official in subject and pronominal class.

gÃ¢ @Hoemai 2025-03-07 #a2boFbpIg $en Â±
pendent particle: allows placing an argument in front and outside of a phrase in order to bind a variable within that phrase
  Hoemai (2025-03-07): Originally I thought that this would just be an empty preposition and therefore precede its complement. But this would require a change to the rules governing adjunct placement and scope, because pendent constructions often appear between subject and object (see examples below), and it would also limit its application.
  Hoemai (2025-03-07): I also seem to prefer the feel of **gÃ¢** as a postposition. Given these points, I propose that **gÃ¢** be like a barnacle.
  Hoemai (2025-03-07): Like a barnacle, it sits on top of whatever (phrase) is right next to it; its host is actually its complement, and the pendent argument itself is the specifier.
  Hoemai (2025-03-07): Example usage: **Shoe jÃ­, sÃ­a raÄ± gÃ¢, ê¡Ã¤ kuq sÃºq rÃ¡Ä±.** "I allow, for no X, that you say X." **Dua jÃ­, sÃ¡ poq gÃ¢, ê¡Ã¤ cho hÃ³ sÃºq.** "I know, of someone, that they like you."
  Hoemai (2025-03-07): Based on Eatoaq's **nÃ¢**, but keeps fronting-**nÃ¤** and pendent-**gÃ¢** syntactically and phonologically distinct.

  mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18): Hi!  I personally think this word is fine as is because the word â€œgayâ€ for example, could mean that someone is homoromantic or homosexual.  There can also exist less specific words.  Of course, more specific words are always welcome, but I think most people would rather say â€œI am straightâ€ than â€œI am heteroromantic and heterosexual.â€
  mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18): As for your note that this word doesnâ€™t mention gender anywhere, the alternative would be heojeqda[mai/romantic-attract/sexual-attract]. You could think of this word as an shortening of that word. Additionally, Toaq compounds are not always just their parts combined. For example, choÄ±shoaÄ± means hawk, but it is a compound word â€œsharp-wingâ€
  mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18): Oh, and @maigoi, the word **heoseaq** exists for heterosexual.
  mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18): Additionally, you are free to coin new words as you like.  Most words in Toaq are created by the community based on need.  For example, this word was coined by @fagri, not Hoemai (the creator of Toaq).  So you are more than welcome to create a word for heteromantic :)
  mimiaoganhaqpy (2024-09-18): You can join us on our Discord server https://discord.gg/Wxn6XF4G to discuss coining words.

I think the definition itself could be more... interesting;

now, I don't think there would need to be a compound of three roots, just a new root for the two of them which are very common!

I have no creativity for creating roots and I made a toki pona words generator, not a Toaq one so, I'm unlucky now xD

I like how the community creates its own words, but I'm seeing my way into Toaq for pure aesthetics, and I highly consider grammar (thus learning a logical language) and well-made compounds (so it doesn't make the grammar useless as 'logical'). those factors are important to me, as I wouldn't a logical language being harder to parse than toki pona, due to... autistic reasons ._.

I don't use Discord but suspect this is bridged;

  uakci (2021-11-06): this is a reformulation of <@official jÄ±oq> that avoids depending on properties as answer-givers. xâ‚‚ may be filled with a proposition or an indirect question
  uakci (2021-11-06): if xâ‚‚ is a (non-interrogative) proposition, the verb means â€œto calculate that xâ‚‚ is the caseâ€; â€œto come to the conclusion that xâ‚‚ is the case through calculation/reckoningâ€
  uakci (2021-11-06): ex.: **jÄ±oq jÃ­ pÃªu pÃ©Ä± jo pÃ©Ä± gu pÃ©Ä± gu** â€“ â€˜I calculate that 2 + 2 = 4â€™
  uakci (2021-11-06): this form may be used in a serial (**jÄ±oq peu jÃ­ pÃ©Ä± jo pÃ©Ä± gu pÃ©Ä± gu** = the same); moreover, you can say **jÄ±oq peu jÃ­** â€˜I addâ€™ (I calculate addition operations)
  uakci (2021-11-06): if xâ‚‚ is a polar interrogative proposition (one with **ma**), this verb means â€œto verify if xâ‚‚ is the caseâ€. xâ‚‚ is not asserted
  uakci (2021-11-06): if xâ‚‚ is an interrogative proposition involving **tÄ±o**, **co**, **hÄ±**, this verb can be translated like the official definition â€“ xâ‚ calculates what the answer to xâ‚‚ is

kalo @jiqci 2023-06-22 #tYmiprJP2 $en Â±
â–¯ is a calorie/kilocalorie.
  jiqci (2023-06-22): there were historically two calories, the large calorie being the amount of energy required to heat 1kg of water by 1 degree, and the small calorie being 1/1000th of that, i.e. heat required for 1-degree change of 1g of water. The term "calorie" nowadays refers to the large calorie, while "kilocalorie" means 1000 of the small calories, i.e. the two are equivalent.

â–¯ creates paste/powder/rubble/fragments â–¯
  Dembim (2026-02-01): Frame: c c
  Dembim (2026-02-01): Pronominal_class: ho
  Dembim (2026-02-01): This is meant as a sort of counterpart to <baÄ±> (which suggests constructive creation) that means creation through destruction/reduction
  Dembim (2026-02-01): Etymology: the sound of a pestle scraping in a mortar

  fagri (2021-10-05): When conjunctions are interpreted as N-ary operations, a chain of kuji's should produce a list that satisfy the property more and more as the list goes on

lÄ±poe @fagri 2019-12-25 #fvr0hGlXw $en Â±
What satisfies property â–¯ is independent of what satisfies property â–¯
  fagri (2019-12-25): In other words, there are no ordered pairs (A, B) that are forbidden from satisfying the properties (P1, P2), unless A is always forbidden from satisfying P1 or B is always forbidden from satisfying P2
  fagri (2019-12-25): Another way of saying the same thing is that the ordered pairs (A, B) that can satisfy (P1, P2) are simply the cross product of the values A that can satisfy P1 and the values B that can satisfy P2
  fagri (2019-12-25): This word only kind of came up in a real context and might turn out to be designed from too high an ivory tower to be useful

meq- @uakci 2023-10-13 #5lDBV3chi $en Â±
prefix: turn verb into focus prefix
  uakci (2023-10-13): see **meq**, **kueu**. the mechanics of this word goes as follows: â€¢if X is binary, then the focus prefix feeds the focused part of a proposition as the first argument and the â€˜remainderâ€™ expressed as a lambda as the second argument. for example, **cho jÃ­ máº¹Ìqsoq sÃºq** transforms into **soq sÃºq, lÃ¤ cho jÃ­ jÃ¡**. in this vein, **máº¹Ìq'Ä±q** corresponds to the no-op focus prefix. note that the original preposition is lifted, i.e., no longer asserted (in favor of the ancillary proposition whose predicate is X); â€¢if X is unary, then the use of the focus prefix is equivalent to an adjoined clause with it replaced by **kÃº** â€“ for example, **cho jÃ­ máº¹ÌqgÄ±faq sÃºq** transforms into **cho jÃ­ sÃºq; gÄ±faq, ê¡Ã¤ cho jÃ® kÃº sÃºq**. note that this use is essentially similar to an eventive adverb (here, **gÃ®faq**), so like a focused/scoped adverbial if you will

meq @Ilmen 2020-01-10 #RSxfBglvT $en +1
quantifier: the proposition in which this quantifier appears is treated as a property with a lambda slot placed exactly where this quantifier appears; the resulting property is then claimed to satisfy the first slot of the predicate introduced by this quantifier.
  Ilmen (2020-01-10): ``má»§Ä±dÅ«a meq ná»a nÃ­`` = ``ná»a mÃ»Ä±dÅ«a ja nÃ­``.
  Ilmen (2020-01-14): ``meq háº£o`` is similar to ``hÃ£o`` but instead of delivering a proposition (lÃ») to the first slot of ``hao`` as is the case with the latter, it passes a property (lÃ®) to it. Compare ``chá»q jÃ­ nÃ­ jáº½aq dáº£qfÄÄ±`` â€”"I use this increasingly frequently"â€” with ``chá»q meq pá»§Ä±jÄ“aq nÃ­`` â€”"increasingly many ones use this"â€”.
  Ilmen (2020-01-14): What can be expressed as ``gá»§aÄ± meq dÃ¹q pÃ³q`` under the alternative definition #46CV57Aje can be expressed as per this very definition as ``gá»§aÄ± pÃ³q ru meq há»pÄ dá»§q``, which is three syllables more. Hopefully the additional flexibility allowed by this one definition is a sufficient compensation.

nhebÄ±o @Dembim 2026-01-29 #U63mt3AsN $en Â±
volume unit: cup (see notes)
  Dembim (2026-01-29): What means "a cup" can be a deeply messy affair. Everyone has their own version of every basic culinary measure. As much as I would like to imagine that Toaqgua is immune to such messiness, as a matter of cold reality, words for real world units are only useful if they accord with the real world. So, this word is for the _contextual_ cup, whatever a cup means to the speaker in the place and time that they speak. One should use the below, more specific words if further precision is required.
  Dembim (2026-01-29): <usonhebÄ±o>, <gomonhebÄ±o>, <nuÄ±nhebÄ±o>, <fuÄ±nhebÄ±o>
  Dembim (2026-01-29): Etymology: lexicalization of <@uakci nhe-> + <@official bÄ±o>

pa @el 2022-10-20 #6GYakxr1u $en -1
argument fronter: takes a single argument (not an adverbial) to its left, and the verbal complex to its right; inserts the left argument between the verb and the first argument on the right
  el (2022-10-20): must appear *after* all **bÄ±**s; cannot be nested
  el (2022-10-20): gritty details: **pa** is a pronounced F head(!) that generates with a VP complement (like current FPs) but also with an empty specifier (unlike them); Spec,V is moved out and into Spec,F, leaving the V' node intact and unmoved
  el (2022-10-20): note that this means that sentences like **jÃ­ pa gÄ± da**, with a unary matrix verb, are ungrammatical
  el (2022-10-20): **jÃ­ pa fáº£ jÃ©arÄ±aq**: [SAP [CP [C Ã˜] [FP Ã˜_1 [F' [F pa] [VP [DP jÃ­<1>] [V' [V fa] [DP [D t2] [V jeariaq]]]]]]] [SA Ã˜]]
  el (2022-10-20): with the DP marked <1> moving up to the node marked _1
  Hoemai (2022-10-20): Looks like this (slightly adjusted): https://dprebyl.github.io/syntree/#%5BSAP%20%5BCP%20%5BC%20%C3%98%5D%20%5BFP%20%5BDP_1%20j%C3%AD%5D%20%5BF'%20%5BF%20pa%5D%20%5BVP%20%5BDP%20t%3C1%3E%5D%20%5BV'%20%5BV%20fa%5D%20%5BDP%20%5BD%20t2%5D%20%5BV%20jeariaq%5D%5D%5D%5D%5D%5D%5D%20%5BSA%20%C3%98%5D%5D

  Laqme (2025-05-07): This is like **Ä±qlÄ±huÄ±** (malgli) but for Toki Pona. It probably mostly describes the kind of "over-analysis" or "oversimplification" that arises as a result of a small lexicon (forcing speakers to speak in Toki Pona-like ways), or just as a result of conlangers sometimes thinking every conlang is like Toki Pona.
  Laqme (2025-05-07): For example: I'd say my old word **kaÄ±nao** for "ink" is ponahuÄ±, and **puÄ±m** is better.

soq @uakci 2022-01-09 #8FtyCn9fR $en +6
â–¯ satisfies property â–¯ the most.
  uakci (2022-01-09): this definition works flawlessly despite serial right-branching â€“ e.g., **soq há»§Ä± pá»q** â€˜the worst personâ€™, **nÄ± sá»q chá»§Ä± tá»‰sha ná»‰** â€˜the first two to arrive hereâ€™
  uakci (2022-01-09): actually, Â»despiteÂ« isnâ€™t even the right word here. the complement of a **soq** serial can be attributive or predicative. if itâ€™s predicative (say, A B), then **soq** sees the property of satisfying A the most (while also being B); if attributive, we still get valid semantics for things like **nuÄ± káº£nÄ±** â€˜small rabbitâ€™, since the **nuÄ±**-est **káº£nÄ±** is also the **nuÄ±**-est thing that is also a **kanÄ±**
  uakci (2022-01-09): in other words, since the extent of an adjectival serial A B is proportional to the extent of A and not A Ã— B (barring situations where B is flat-out false), **soq** will look at the correct Â»partÂ« of the serial
  uakci (2022-01-09): yet another way to look at it: in an adjectival serial such as A B, the A part is qualitative (how *much* something is A), whereas the B part is quantitative (*if* that thing is B *at all*). so rather than A Ã— B we have something like the *truth value* of B times the *extent* of Aa
  uakci (2022-01-09): if you agree with these postulates, you'll find this definition of **soq** unobjectionable
  uakci (2022-01-09): CORRECTION: the example beginning in **nÄ± sá»q chá»§Ä±â€¦** should read **gu sá»q chá»§Ä±â€¦** instead
  el (2022-01-11): this definition also works very well with **meabÄ±**, and that means **suÄ±** can be defined similar to this

sÃ³q @uakci 2023-01-21 #1cKmcwq_t $en +1
focus particle: the most
  uakci (2023-01-21): extending hoemaÄ±'s analysis of english focus adverbs such as 'only' and 'even', which actually pair with sentence-level stress-based focus, we can see that 'the most' works similarly: '*I* like apples the most' (more than other people) vs. 'I like *apples* the most' (more than I do other fruit/food). **soq** used to be really inconvenient in convoluted situations and usually required a confusing **lu** clause to work at all, whereas this approach should feel much more natural
  uakci (2023-01-21): see also 'prior work': **sojÄ±** (which is a RU)
  uakci (2023-01-21): related grammatical discussion (esp. the 'association with focus' part) https://toaq.net/refgram/syntax/#focusing_adverbs
  robintown (2023-11-06): this is maybe a good translation for 'especially'

ê Ã¤ tÄ± sÃºq nÃ­, bÃ¯ jaÄ± jÃ­. @robintown 2023-10-29 #sL7_nzMNF $en Â±
I'm happy that you're here.
  robintown (2023-10-30): Lynn and I had a discussion about this, where we concluded that neither **kÃ»Ä±** or **gÃªm** really make sense for this meaning. As adjuncts, both constructions imply that you are, on the whole, happy. But imagine a situation in which you're having a bad day, and a friend comes to comfort you: you might say "I'm happy that you're here" even if it wouldn't be genuine to say "I'm happy". We found a paper https://www.semanticsarchive.net/Archive/DIzYWZkM/clauses.doc which claims that the clausal constituent participates in the semantics by a "regarding" relation, which suggests that a topic is the appropriate construction in Toaq. And there's similar evidence in Japanese to support this.

  uakci (2021-08-23): **P say Q** is taken to mean: âˆƒx.Px â‡’ [âˆƒx.Px] Qx. in other words, the claim is tautologically true if the quantification fails
  uakci (2021-08-23): also known as existential quantification without existential import â€“ that is to say, unlike **sa P**, **say P** doesn't presuppose that P is satisfiable (that an x such that Px exists to begin with)

  kazoo (2025-11-09): then what is the fundamental difference between an event of... and a fact of...
  kazoo (2025-11-09): (unrelated to shu)
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): A proposition is abstract, it contains only the information that is given in it and nothing more; a proposition can entail any less detailed version of it (â€œa tall man wears a blue hatâ€ â†’ â€œa man wears a hatâ€), and any more detailed proposition similarly entails the first one, forming a hierarchy of level of detailedness / amount of information.
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): The way I understand events is that they are individual entities, presumably spatiotemporal entities but I think it's possible to extend them to non-spationtempral worlds (so that â€œan event of 1 = âˆš1â€ would make sense)
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): It is possible to conceive individuals and propositions as belonging to a single supertype, in such a way that an individual is an infinitely or maximally detailed proposition, so that, unlike standard proposition, an event cannot entail or be instantiated by a â€œmore detailed eventâ€
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): So that it would be like a terminal node in the hierarchy of abstractness/detailedness
  kazoo (2025-11-09): 
  kazoo (2025-11-09): 
  kazoo (2025-11-09): i keep hitting the enter button
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): As a side note, âŸªê¡Ã¤âŸ« and âŸªbÃ¡q Ã«âŸ« could possibly be equivalent in effect
  kazoo (2025-11-09): :thinking emoji:
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): But I'm not sure, the semantics of âŸªbÃ¡qâŸ« seem to have changed in KÃºna, and I've not yet studied new-bÃ¡qâ€¦
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Anyway, people say that tone ^ is associated with events, but this might clash with my theory of â€œevents are indiviuals reifying propositionsâ€
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): I've started to doubt that verbs like âŸ¦caâŸ§ deal with individual events instead of propositions
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): When you say âŸªpushing this button causes the door to openâŸ«, you're not thinking of a specific fully detailed and concrete event of pushing the button
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): If you did, we wouldn't know whether the real cause would be unspoken details about the event
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): But with an adverb like âŸªdeâŸ«, you do want to talk about unspoken details
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): âŸªhe danced funnilyâŸ« means that some unspoken details of a concrete event instantiating âŸªhe dancesâŸ« are funny
  evie (2025-11-09): yea i think shÃª works better there. shÃª wÃ¡ someone pushes the button nÃ¤ the door opens
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): it's not just the abstract idea that he dances that is funny
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Maybe we could also say that âŸªdÃªâŸ« is actually not good and that we should use âŸªchÃ¢ sÃ¡ deâŸ«
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Or we could say that âŸªdeâŸ«'s type require an individual, concrete reading, unlike e.g. âŸªcaâŸ«

  Ilmen (2025-11-09): It's not just âŸªcaâŸ«, imagine also âŸªboqâŸ«

  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Oh I tend to forget âŸªÃ©âŸ« isn't a (regular) complementizer like ê¡a
  kazoo (2025-11-09): unrelatedly, ive been working on a new language whose grammar could be considered improved toaq gamma with a hint of delta proposals
  kazoo (2025-11-09): a lot of my langs lately have been coincidentally similar to toaq so i've decided to embrace the toaqness now
  kazoo (2025-11-09): it takes some surface-level inspiration with other sinitic languages with its phonology
  kazoo (2025-11-09): it only has Ã« and lÃ¤ clauses as complementizers and the other clause "type"s are constructed by just attaching it to a noun as a plain ol ~adjective
  kazoo (2025-11-09): so that it can be more flexible
  kazoo (2025-11-09): (c.f. 300 different NU particles of lojban)
  kazoo (2025-11-09): it tries to bring the "everything is a predicate" even further
  kazoo (2025-11-09): compared to toaq im planning to make it basically like loglan vs lojban except its a coexisting fun alternative rather than an improvement
  kazoo (2025-11-09): i think toaq as it is is already cool, i just like to make stuff that would keep the level of coolness
  kazoo (2025-11-09): it also primarily switches to monadic second-(/higher?-)order logic which is expressively the same as plural logic but uses sets which is more intuitive to me
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Nothing wrong with making new Toaq-inspired languages :')
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): You can have modified setsâ€¦ You probably don't want empty sets in the way, do you?
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): On the other hand, nested sets may be useful
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Some forms of Plural Logic allows for nested plurals, but with important constrants
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): E.g. you can have the equivalent of {{A, B}, {C, D}}, but not {{A, B}, C, D}
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): And the former is not of the same type as {A, B}
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): (first-order plural vs second-order plural, basically)
  kazoo (2025-11-09): i see
  kazoo (2025-11-09): i also briefly considered abolishing the universal quantifier by using a special object incorporation construction, basically resulting as "there is a set that has an instance of all humans; which satisfies aliveness"
  kazoo (2025-11-09): but i do not know if this would work for all instances of universal quantification
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): With empty sets allowed, and saying that each member of the set individually has the property, then it works for a singular universal quantifier
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Eberban doesn't have quantifiers and use predicates instead
  kazoo (2025-11-09): yeah im just gonna make it sÃ¡ by default and make the rest with predicates
  kazoo (2025-11-09): i decided that because i randomly remembered once that the wiki says to append shÄ± to the argument to mimic singularity and i thought "why is this not made for every determiner??"
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): There used to be âŸªtÃºshÄ±âŸ« at one point in the past
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): But it was decided that it was more frequently used than plural universal, so âŸªtÃºshÄ±âŸ«'s meaning was transposed over âŸªtÃºâŸ«
  kazoo (2025-11-09): thats a little bit funny lol, the newer concept being swapped with the normal one
  kazoo (2025-11-09): tho i meant that every determiner should instead be a predicate
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Have you looked into my YaÄ±gawe? All quantifiers are derived from verbs with a â€œquantifierizerâ€ suffix.
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): NahaÄ±wa can do that too, but it has morphological shorthand for some common determiners
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): As for what is the unmarked default quantifier for themâ€¦ Originally my idea was that the default would be lowest-scope existential quantification, but now I'm considering the possibility to have the default be a bÃ¡q-like intension (i.e. not necessarily referring to a concrete individual)
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): So that âŸªbeautiful-V dog-NOMâŸ« would mean âŸªdogness is beautifulâŸ« rather than âŸªthere exist a beautiful dogâŸ«
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Hmm maybe this should depend on modality too
  Ilmen (2025-11-09): Oh, don't forget the anaphoric determiner, Toaq's raising tone, which can't quite be rendered as a predicate
